messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Is the space complexity of planted clique recovery the same as that of detection?

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the planted clique problem in which a clique of size kğ‘˜k is planted in an ErdÅ‘s-RÃ©nyi graph Gâ€‹(n,12)ğºğ‘›12G(n,\frac{1}{2}), and one is interested in either detecting or recovering this planted clique. This problem is interesting because it is widely believed to show a statistical-computational gap at clique size k=Î˜â€‹(n)ğ‘˜Î˜ğ‘›k=\Theta(\sqrt{n}), and has emerged as the prototypical problem with such a gap from which average-case hardness of other statistical problems can be deduced. It also displays a tight computational connection between the detection and recovery variants, unlike other problems of a similar nature. This wide investigation into the computational complexity of the planted clique problem has, however, mostly focused on its time complexity. To begin investigating the robustness of these statistical-computational phenomena to changes in our notion of computational efficiency, we ask- Do the statistical-computational phenomena that make the planted clique an interesting problem also hold when we use â€˜space efficiencyâ€™ as our notion of computational efficiency? It is relatively easy to show that a positive answer to this question depends on the existence of a Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) space algorithm that can recover planted cliques of size k=Î©â€‹(n)ğ‘˜Î©ğ‘›k=\Omega(\sqrt{n}). Our main result comes very close to designing such an algorithm. We show that for k=Î©â€‹(n)ğ‘˜Î©ğ‘›k=\Omega(\sqrt{n}), the recovery problem can be solved in Oâ€‹((logâˆ—â¡nâˆ’logâˆ—â¡kn)â‹…logâ¡n)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘›O\left(\left(\log^{*}{n}-\log^{*}{\frac{k}{\sqrt{n}}}\right)\cdot\log n\right) bits of space. 1. If k=Ï‰â€‹(nâ€‹log(â„“)â¡n)ğ‘˜ğœ”ğ‘›superscriptâ„“ğ‘›k=\omega(\sqrt{n}\log^{(\ell)}n) 111Here log(â„“)â¡nsuperscriptâ„“ğ‘›\log^{(\ell)}n means we repeatedly take the logarithm of nğ‘›n â„“â„“\ell times. For example, log(3)â¡n=logâ¡logâ¡logâ¡nsuperscript3ğ‘›ğ‘›\log^{(3)}n=\log\log\log n. for any constant integer â„“>0â„“0\ell>0, the space usage is Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) bits. 2. If k=Î˜â€‹(n)ğ‘˜Î˜ğ‘›k=\Theta(\sqrt{n}), the space usage is Oâ€‹(logâˆ—â¡nâ‹…logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptâ‹…ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\log^{*}{n}\cdot\log n) bits. Our result suggests that there does exist an Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) space algorithm to recover cliques of size k=Î©â€‹(n)ğ‘˜Î©ğ‘›k=\Omega(\sqrt{n}), since we come very close to achieving such parameters. This provides evidence that the statistical-computational phenomena that (conjecturally) hold for planted clique time complexity also (conjecturally) hold for space complexity.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Testing k-wise and almost k-wise independence",
        "Computational complexity: a modern approach",
        "Community detection and stochastic block models: recent developments",
        "Algorithmic barriers from phase transitions",
        "Finding a large hidden clique in a random graph",
        "Achieving the ks threshold in the general stochastic block model with linearized acyclic belief propagation",
        "Nuclear norm minimization for the planted clique and biclique problems",
        "Reducibility and statistical-computational gaps from secret leakage",
        "Reducibility and computational lower bounds for problems with planted sparse structure",
        "Computationally efficient robust sparse estimation in high dimensions",
        "Cliques in random graphs",
        "A nearly tight sum-of-squares lower bound for the planted clique problem",
        "Complexity theoretic lower bounds for sparse principal component detection",
        "Statistical-computational tradeoffs in planted problems and submatrix localization with a growing number of clusters and submatrices",
        "Finding hidden cliques in linear time with high probability",
        "Asymptotic analysis of the stochastic block model for modular networks and its algorithmic applications",
        "Linear programming is log-space hard for p",
        "Finding hidden cliques of size N/eğ‘ğ‘’\\sqrt{N/e} in nearly linear time",
        "Improved sum-of-squares lower bounds for hidden clique and hidden submatrix problems",
        "On approximating the eigenvalues of stochastic matrices in probabilistic logspace",
        "On the problem of approximating the eigenvalues of undirected graphs in probabilistic logspace",
        "Statistical algorithms and a lower bound for detecting planted cliques",
        "Finding and certifying a large hidden clique in a semirandom graph",
        "The probable value of the lovÃ¡szâ€“schrijver relaxations for maximum independent set",
        "Finding hidden cliques in linear time",
        "The landscape of the planted clique problem: Dense subgraphs and the overlap gap property",
        "The power of sum-of-squares for detecting hidden structures",
        "On the integrality gap of degree-4 sum of squares for planted clique",
        "Statistical inference and the sum of squares method",
        "Concentration of the hypergeometric distribution",
        "Bayesian estimation from few samples: community detection and related problems",
        "Computational lower bounds for community detection on random graphs",
        "Large cliques elude the metropolis process",
        "Sum of squares lower bounds for refuting any csp",
        "Expected complexity of graph partitioning problems",
        "Notes on computational hardness of hypothesis testing: Predictions using the low-degree likelihood ratio",
        "Robust sparse estimation tasks in high dimensions",
        "Phase transitions in sparse pca",
        "Lectures on combinatorial statistics",
        "Finding planted cliques in sublinear time",
        "Community detection thresholds and the weak ramanujan property",
        "Consistency thresholds for the planted bisection model",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for planted clique",
        "A statistical model for tensor pca",
        "On the constant-depth complexity of k-clique",
        "The monotone complexity of k-clique on random graphs",
        "Finding a planted clique by adaptive probing",
        "Randomization and derandomization in space-bounded computation",
        "Approximating linear programming is log-space complete for p",
        "Computational barriers to estimation from low-degree polynomials",
        "Mathematics and Computation: A Theory Revolutionizing Technology and Science"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Is the space complexity of planted clique recovery the same as that of detection?, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
